Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Gendered Nature of Intergroup Bias

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration: This CAREER project focuses on the problem of intergroup bias and considers the way that gender affects its expression. Drawing from two influential theories within social psychology known as social identity theory and social dominance theory, the proposed research examines the psychology of antipathy towards men of social out-groups. In carrying out this research, the PI tests a major component of social dominance theory previously dubbed "the subordinate male target hypothesis," and extends it to a more general "out-group male target hypothesis" that is consistent with the aims of the proposal. Specifically, this highly innovative project examines the way that men and women psychologically represent intergroup bias differently, and the way that the gender of the out-group target affects how those representations are expressed. Do men and women have different motivational systems that account for extreme reactions to out-group males? The research proposed addresses this question and other related ones with a rich methodology that includes eight experiments that (a) employ aversive conditioning protocols using group/gender categories as target stimuli, (b) assess the effect of menstrual cycle timing on implicit bias against out-group men, and (c) explore reasoning biases in moral dilemmas that require behavioral responses with life or death consequences of individuals from various social categories within artificial, yet realistic virtual environments. Ultimately, this research will permit a fuller understanding of the psychological mechanisms underlying this particular form of out-group animus, and shed light on the impacts of gender, physiological states, as well as judgments and actions in moral dilemmas on the expression of bias.

POR.DRECONTENT:
I have conducted my work using the broad hypothesis that the psychology underlying prejudice against outgroups may fundamentally differ between men and women. Specifically, my approach focuses on how men and women differ in coping with the threats posed specifically by outgroup men, and how such threats relate to the perceiver’s gender-specific psychology. Based on concepts rooted in behavioral ecology, as well as mainstream social psychological research, I posit that male intergroup psychology may be characterized by dominance motives and aggression, whereas female intergroup representations are characterized by wariness and fear. This perspective generates the expectation that both men and women will generally be more prejudiced against outgroup men relative to outgroup women, but for different reasons. Therefore, I have been building a theoretical and empirical case for the idea that individual differences in the psychological traits, states, and risk profiles relevant to intergroup bias may be patterned along the lines of aggressive dominance striving for men, and fearful avoidance for women.

Sex Differences in Animus Toward Outgroup Men. Building on the observation that learned fear is less readily extinguished to natural hazards (e.g., predators) compared to non-natural hazards (e.g. electrical cords), I have shown that fear conditioned to outgroup exemplars resists extinction only when the exemplars are male, not female. Importantly, I have shown that such learning biases are associated with fear of sexual coercion among female research participants, and the fusion of aggression and social dominance orientation among male participants. My most recent work in fear conditioning show that learning biases are not limited to intergroup contexts defined by race, and are found even in a “minimal group paradigm,” where memberships in ad hoc groups are determined by arbitrary criteria, such as t-shirt color.

Intergroup Bias and Conception Risk Across the Menstrual Cycle. Consonant with a wide range of research in behavioral biology that affirms the critical importance of female reproductive choice in humans and other animals, there is reason to expect that negativity toward out-group men may be strongest for women when the costs of sexual coercion are greatest—namely, during the fertile phase of the menstrual cycle when conception risk is high. This is because outgroup men appraised as deviant and dangerous may be perceived as posing a greater risk to a woman’s control, maintenance and exercise of her own reproductive interests. Although such appraisals of male strangers are undoubtedly of emotional importance at any point in a woman’s life, such sensitivities may be of particular functional importance when the costs of coercion have their gravest consequences in terms of reproductive fitness—during the fertile phase of the menstrual cycle. Thus, a hazard heuristic against out-group men may overwhelm a woman’s prevailing preference for novelty when the outgroup male target is perceived as dangerously formidable or when she appraises herself to be vulnerable to coercion, such that such heuristics may serve to increase negativity directed at outgroup men as a function of a woman’s risk profile. 

Accordingly, I have found that as conception risk increases across the cycle, so does anti-Black race bias (see Figure 1), and that this effect is moderated by the fear of sexual coercion. Such biases also apply in a minimal group paradigm, particularly when outgroup men are perceived as physically formidable.
